editorialDecl.p: Edgeworth’s spelling and punctuation are retained in transcription, including non-standard spelling, line breaks, and hyphenation of words. The long s and ligatured forms are silently emended.

div.p:
I have received a note this day from
Mr Ward, which assures me of his entire
confidence in his chief messengers honesty
& accuracy. "I cannot doubt" says he "that
Mr Crewe franked it upon his recollection
but the messenger cannot remember, whether
the packet was delivered to the man who
brought it, or went with the office letters".

As you will see by the note
from Mr Crewe & by the letters I enclosed
you from the Post office, it is notwithstanding
Mr Wards believe to the contrary, most
probable that the packet never was franked
by Mr Crewe and was never put into the
Post office. My only remaining chance
is to your having it to your own messenger or
to his own immaculate messenger --

If as I believe that shawl cannot be re
covered recovered I must set the loss down to the
of my own childish impatience & after
this seven guinea check resolve to be wiser
in future & save the money on something
else. My eagerness however, (I won't call
it impatience this time) to present a shawl
to my dear Aunt, is yet unabated, but I will
be wise and patient this time as to the means of getting it over - A friend
come over, in the course of the next month who
will bring it over & in the course of the
next fortnight I will send you accurate
directions - If you are not tired of buying
Shawls & are not afraid of again suffering
anxiety, I will begin the business over
again, thus, Buy me a Crimson or a

Morone Colour, the border narrow, the border
of the first white shawl you sent me, was
elegant, & well put on, the border of the last
Green Shawl, was ill put on & the corners
ill turned down, so that it betrayed it to be
an imitation - I think more of the
of the colour & of the elegance of the border than
the size, the white shawl was quite large
enough. As to the price, I don't limit
you, for I can pinch it out of of anything else
as I wish to have the Shawl for my Aunt
handsome and elegant -

Do pray tell me something of the Man
who is going out to India to improve the
there? I have the great pleasure
to tell you that my father has been consider
ably better for the last two or three days.
I hope this may find Mr. Miles as well
as we wish him to be. I hope you received
the draught for £6..10..0 -
div.closer:
I am dear
Madam your obliged and troublesome Servant
Maria Edgeworth
